title: Question 233

children: A 22-year-old woman is evaluated because of nontraumatic anterior left knee pain that began after training for a triathlon competition. The pain worsens with running, squatting, climbing stairs, or sitting for an extended time.
Examination reveals pain with direct pressure to the patella and while squatting. There is no other tenderness or swelling.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Patellofemoral pain syndrome is characterized by anterior knee pain and/or stiffness that is worse with knee flexion during weight-bearing activity such as running, climbing stairs, and squatting, but pain is also worse after prolonged flexion with sitting.
Patellar pain with squatting has 91% sensitivity as a physical examination sign for patellofemoral pain syndrome.
This patient has patellofemoral pain syndrome (

). Patellofemoral pain syndrome is caused by disordered patellar tracking with knee movement. Risk factors include female sex (due to higher Q-angle in women); patellar instability; weakness of the quadriceps; and physical activities such as climbing stairs, running, and squatting. It is characterized by anterior knee pain and/or stiffness that is worse with knee flexion during weight-bearing activity such as climbing stairs, running, and squatting, but pain is also worse after prolonged flexion with sitting. On physical examination, applying pressure to the patella may reproduce pain. There is also exacerbation of pain with squatting, which has 91% sensitivity as a physical examination sign. NSAIDs may help alleviate symptoms in the acute setting but have not shown benefit in the long term. In the acute phase of injury, modification of activity and cryotherapy (ice, cold water immersion) is recommended. In the recovery phase, the most effective treatment for patellofemoral pain syndrome is physical therapy with an exercise program designed to strengthen the quadriceps, hamstrings, and gluteus muscles. Core strengthening exercises may also have benefit.

Patients with acute meniscal tears are usually able to bear weight immediately. On examination, effusions, if present, are generally small to moderate in size. This patient has no symptoms or findings consistent with meniscal tear.
Pes anserine pain syndrome (also known as pes anserine bursitis) (

), common in athletes and runners, classically presents with pain localized to the proximal anteromedial tibia. On physical examination, tenderness is localized to the anteromedial aspect of the knee about 6 cm below the joint line. This finding is not present in this patient.

Pain occurs superior to the patella (quadriceps tendinopathy) or distal to the patella (patellar tendinopathy) and can be reproduced with palpation of the affected area. This patient has pain directly over the patella, an unlikely presentation of quadriceps tendinopathy.
